items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides, however high tides will remain high for the next few days in association with this set of springs. We do not expect to issue any further alerts or warnings. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message: Thursday's early morning tide at 01:15 on 29/05/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days, and accompanied by light Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather still increases tide table values by 0.09 m. The total forecast tide is 5.99 metres Chart Datum (2.94 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Over the next five days, light winds and small waves are forecast, and with tides lower no more than minimal flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding could be possible.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
Heavy rain will continue throughout the morning (29/05/2025) but is forecast to ease off into the afternoon. Flooding is still possible.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 29/05/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Lancashire, North Yorkshire, Westmorland and Furness

items.message:
Flooding is possible from 11:00 AM on 29/05/2025.
Areas most at risk include River Lune, Conder and Keer and other watercourses from Kirkby Lonsdale to Galgate including Gressingham, Carnforth, Hornby, Wray, Bentham and Lancaster.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 29/05/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The risk of flooding is reduced with more settled conditions expected. We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue this alert if the situation changes.

Flooding is possible from 10:30 AM on 29/05/2025.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Ribble, Hodder and other watercourses, from Settle to Samlesbury including Clitheroe, Gisburn, Sawley, Waddington and Ribchester.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 29/05/2025, or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon but no further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Groundwater levels affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas of Welwyn are continuing to reduce.
 
No further flooding to low lying land, roads and gardens is expected. We have seen low rainfall totals over previous weeks, and the forecast is expected to remain dry over the coming days.
 
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
 
Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts if necessary.
